div.marquee: COVID-19 (Corona Virus): If you feel you may have been exposed to COVID-19, call the Womack Army Medical Center's Public Health hotline at (910) 916-3544.

video.source: Your browser doesn't support the HTML5 video tag.

article.p: Maj. Aaron Farmer, Chief of Infectious Disease at Womack Army Medical Center, explains the basics of the novel coronavirus strain COVID-19, from transmission to proximity risk assessment, as well as preventive measures to keep the virus from spreading.

h4.a: Womack Army Medical Center COVID-19 updates
Family and MWR facility and program COVID-19 updates

article.p: If you’re still unsure about the difference between quarantine vs Isolation, or what to do should you be placed in these categories, check this out. You’re not alone, it is easy to get confused with all this information floating around from many sources. We hope we have cleared it up with the below quick reference.

div.h2: Why prevent the spread of COVID-19?

div.p: Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) is the disease caused by a new respiratory virus first seen in Wuhan Province, China in December of 2019. Since that time, it has spread globally, and cases are now occurring across the United States. We are still learning about how the virus impacts people, but available information shows it can be a serious, and even fatal illness for individuals over 60 years of age, and for those with existing health conditions that lower immunity or strain the respiratory system. While COVID-19 appears to impact younger and healthy populations less severely, we all have a responsibility to protect other members of our community.

p.br: Quarantine is a period or place of segregation in which people that may have been exposed to infectious or contagious diseases are placed. It is important, because it limits the spread of illnesses, even from those who may not know they are ill. The quarantine period for COVID-19 is fourteen days. It is important to understand that being in quarantine does not mean that someone is ill.

div.p: For the Individual. Anyone placed in quarantine or isolation will be told to avoid close contact (under six feet) with others,not share personal items, sleep in a separate bedroom, clean and sanitize surfaces, cough or sneeze into their elbow, and use a separate bathroom, if possible. They should not travel or visit public areas, nor use public transportation. They should limit interaction with pets or other animals to the extent possible. An individual in quarantine should monitor their temperature twice each day and should self-assess how they feel. If they become ill, they should contact their medical provider. They should not seek care without pre-coordinating with the medical facility, so that the medical facility can receive them appropriately.

For Family Members.Family members of someone in quarantine are not restricted from movement. They are able to leave the residence to attend school, go to the grocery store, and attend other events as they normally would. While at home, they should avoid close contact with the family member who is in quarantine, they should wash their hands regularly, and should practice cough hygiene.

p.br: Anyone placed in quarantine or isolation will be told to avoid close contact (under six feet) with others, not share personal items,sleep in a separate bedroom, clean and sanitize surfaces, cough or sneeze into their elbow, and use a separate bathroom, if possible. They should not travel or visit public areas,nor use public transportation. They should limit interaction with pets or other animals to the extent possible. An individual in quarantine should monitor their temperature twice each day and should self-assess how they feel. If they become ill, they should contact their medical provider. They should not seek care without pre-coordinating with the medical facility, so that the medical facility can receive them appropriately.

div.p: For the Individual. Anyone placed in isolation should immediately separate themselves from others. They should remain in a separate room of the residence and should not share common items or a bathroom, as much as possible. They should continue to practice sanitation practices and cough hygiene, just as they were in quarantine. However, they must make greater efforts tore main separate from others.

For Family Members. Family members of someone in isolation must make every effort to avoid close contact and must wash hands frequently. Family members of someone in isolation may then require quarantine, but that decision requires evaluation by public health.

article.p: With the current state of COVID-19 (Corona Virus), below are downloadable posters for education purposes.

aside.p: Non-DoD Personnel Access Request to Fort Bragg during Heightened HPCON levels. This is a request for the individual listed below to gain access to Fort Bragg for 90 days.
aside.h4: Click to download the PDF form:
aside.h2: Fort Bragg Installation Status as of April 21, 2020:
aside.p: Good evening, Fort Bragg community! Here are the installation updates for today:​​​​

div.p: The trusted traveler program, which requires only the driver to show their ID, will stop at midnight tonight. Beginning at 0001 hours on Wednesday, April 22, all occupants in a vehicle over the age of 18 must show a form of government issued ID. Non-DoD passengers and/or passengers without a DoD issued ID card must have a current and valid pass in addition to an official form of identification. For those visitors without a pass, the Visitor Control Center at All American gate is now open 24 hours a day to process visitor passes. As a reminder, Exception to Policy (ETP) procedures for out of town visitors are still in effect. As it’s been a while since we’ve posted it, here is a link with more information: https://home.army.mil/bragg/index.php/about/covid-19. Non-DoD ID Card holders without a valid pass will NOT be allowed onto Fort Bragg.

In addition to stopping the trusted traveler program, the names of all Service Members, dependents, DA Civilians and Contractors from Fort Bragg, who are under quarantine will be entered into a database used at all ACPs (gates). Any currently quarantined individual entering Fort Bragg through an ACP will be flagged and they will be notified that they are in violation of quarantine. The service member WILL be allowed onto Fort Bragg, but the chain of command or supervisor will be notified. Once the service member is released from quarantine, their name will come off the database. Service Members will still be allowed to come onto Fort Bragg for medical appointments. Individuals found violating quarantine may be subject to adverse action, to include UCMJ and a bar to post.

Minimum Mission Essential Manning is currently in effect until April 29, 2020. A decision on whether or not to extend will be made in the future. Service Members, DA Civilians and Contractors should contact their chain of command or supervisor for additional information.

We want to thank all of you for your diligence and support in wearing of face coverings. You will no longer see MPs doing daily checks for compliance, but that doesn't mean you can now slack off! Remember - do the right thing, even when no one is looking (but who are we kidding? People ARE looking and you WILL be judged by all your fellow shoppers!) The directive still remains though, so we appreciate your continued adherence to protect all of us. In the words of Jerry Maguire - "Help us, help you!"

Have you ever looked at Congress and thought, “I can tell them how to spend all that money the right way.” Well now you can by participating in the 2020 Census. It’s easy, quick and you can do it online, https://2020census.gov/en.html, by phone or through the mail.
All you have to do is answer questions about your household as it was on April 1, 2020. Everyone in the house counts equally, everyone.

The census determines two major items for the nation, the number of congressional representatives and where billions of Federal dollars will be spent on schools, fire departments, hospitals, roads, infrastructure projects and other items designed to keep the country running.
For active duty service members, or a Reserves or Guard member on active duty orders, stationed here at Fort Bragg, your circumstances will determine how you are counted in the 2020 Census:
∙ If you are living in housing on Fort Bragg: You can respond to the census online, by phone, or by mail. Your residence is Fort Bragg, NC, not your state of residence.

∙ If you are living in a barracks on Fort Bragg: The Census Bureau will identify a military point of contact on your base to ensure that you are counted. This could mean completing the census form yourself. Your residence is Fort Bragg, NC, not your state of residence.

∙ If you were deployed outside the United States on April 1, 2020: Using existing data provided by the Department of Defense, the Census Bureau will count you at the U.S. residence where you live and sleep most of the time, i.e. Fort Bragg.

The Army Emergency Relief Campaign is still ongoing even though COVID-19 is happening. As everyone is teleworking and not at work we still would like to give you a avenue or another option to be able to donate to your fellow soldiers.
Online donations:
1. Donors wishing to contribute via debit /credit card may do so by visiting the AER website at www.aerhq.org and click on "Make a Donation" and " Donate Now"
2. Using this method, donors must select Fort Bragg and their assigned unit in order to receive Campaign credit for their donation here at Fort Bragg.
3. Please update assigned Unit Campaign Manager if a unit plan has already been established.

The ID Card Center in the SSC is open for emergencies such as lost, damaged, expired ID cards and ID cards expiring within 30 days; new hires, and CAC PIN resets. Limited appointments for emergencies are available online.
Ryder Golf Course is closed for maintenance through April 23. The Pro Shop will be open from 9 a.m. to 3 p.m.
∙ Stryker Golf Course remains open for regular play. Social distancing is being enforced.
∙ The Divot is open for grab and go orders daily from 7 a.m. to 2 p.m.
∙ McKellar's Range will be open for normal business on Wednesday, April 22 from 11 a.m. to dusk

We know there are still a few of you who have questions out there, but we recommend everyone do each other a favor, and secure some type of face covering (doesn't have to be a mask). Ensure you have it handy in the event you go somewhere where you can’t maintain 6-feet of social distancing that requires a face covering, or if you are asked to wear one, even if you don't think you have to. Think of it like that extra magazine (not the kind you roll up to swat flies with) - It’s better to have it and not need it, than need it and not have it!

Remember, a face covering can be homemade, but your mouth and nose should be covered. Pulling your T-Shirt up over your face is NOT a proper face covering. Please keep in mind that masks or face coverings are not advised for children under 2 years of age or for individuals with difficulty breathing . . . AND, face coverings are not a substitute for physical distancing.

Finally, if you are in an on-post establishment and someone asks you to cover your face, please be nice and put one on. There’s no need for pushback or raised voices. We know these are trying times for everyone, but, let’s remember, all of us are trying to do the right thing, and we are all in this together!
Remember, my face covering protects you, and your face covering protects me.

As we celebrate April the Month of the Military Child, we are deeply thankful to all military children for their courage and resilience in the face of adversity. The current situation with COVID-19 has presented new challenges but, to nobody’s surprise, our military children are handling every change with confidence and grace.

As we continue to monitor how virtual learning is working and based on your feedback, we have made adjustments to our digital learning structure and content. We have standardized the approximate amount of time to be spent on daily instruction, which includes virtual face-to-face sessions and assigned work, with the focus of decreasing screen fatigue. In addition, we are designating Wednesdays as a day in which we want to minimize the screen time for both students and teachers. Teachers will provide students assignments for Wednesdays that do not require screen time. We are asking teachers to focus on essential learning. Teachers will provide parents a preview of the essential learning tasks for the week on Mondays. Students will have until the following Sunday night to turn in the essential learning tasks. This will allow parents who are working and/or have multiple children additional time to support their children. With the increased options and flexibility, it is our hope we will further support the instructional needs of our students and families.

At Womack Army Medical Center, the primary screening will take place at all entrances. If the primary screening is positive, the person will be sent to a secondary screening location, this is even for those with a scheduled appointment. Emergent patients should present to the emergency department entrance and receive a primary and secondary screening in the emergency department.
Secondary screenings will determine if the patient is:
• Sent to the external testing site at Womack Army Medical Center, on Loop Road past the helipad on the right hand side of the road (no symptoms, mild symptom, or no medical concerns).

• Sent to urgent care clinic as the internal testing site (mild to moderate symptoms), the urgent care clinic can facilitate COVID-19 screening and testing, as well as provide resource specialties to treat the patient and complete the scheduled appointment within the urgent care environment.
• Sent to emergency department, if medically compromised, the emergency department staff will treat, test and/or admit the patient to the hospital.

As a reminder, all patients are requested to use the All-American entrance as the Reilly Road entrance is being reserved for staff. Emergent patients should present to the emergency department entrance and receive a primary and secondary screening in the emergency department.
You can always reach a healthcare advice nurse 24/7 at 1-800-TRICARE, option 1.
Still CLOSED. Rocky didn’t need a gym to beat Ivan Drago

aside.p: You may have seen these signs throughout Fort Bragg. First off, don’t panic. If you are outside of the building or room it is posted on, you are not at any greater chance of catching the COVID-19 virus then the rest of us.
What we, and especially our first responders, do need is your help.
The XVIII Airborne Corps requires anyone residing on the installation, whether in the barracks, a house, hotel, etc., is quarantined to visibly display this sign on their door and on the facility.
We are asking for everyone's help in ensuring this directive is followed and are doing all they can to safeguard everyone and especially our First Responders
